articles.author: Rakesh KR
articles.description:
Amazon Cognito is a simple user identity and data synchronization service that helps securely manage and synchronize mobile app data.
Amazon Cognito lets you add user sign-up, sign-in, and access control to your web and mobile apps quickly and easily. Amazon Cognito scales to millions of users and supports sign-in with social identity providers, such as Apple, Facebook, Google, and Amazon, and enterprise identity providers via SAML 2.0 and OpenID Connect.
You can use the optional Amazon Cognito client SDKs to automatically create a local data store to cache user app data on the device. This means your app can keep reading and writing data regardless of the device connectivity state.
With Amazon Cognito you can easily synchronize app data across all of an end userâ€™s devices. Amazon Cognito manages the complexity of conflict resolution and intermittent network connectivity so that your app can always deliver a great user experience.





  
  
  Control Access to AWS Resources


You can use the unique user identifiers that Amazon Cognito generates in your access policies to enable or restrict access to other AWS resources on a per-user basis.
When you use Amazon Cognito, the service takes care of all the steps necessary to create a unique identifier for your appâ€™s users and retrieve temporary, limited privilege AWS credentials.
AWS Cognito can interoperate with AWS SES, AWS SNS, AWS Lambda, and more.
http://aws.amazon.com/cognito/
articles.title: In One Minute : Amazon Cognito

The imperative toolkit you should use to display your frontend skills.
You have developed reusable components, functions or the whole UI library, and now the time comes to showcase, then the Storybook is precisely meant for you.
Check the link, How I showcase my work using Storybook
A storybook is a tool for UI development. It makes development faster and easier by isolating components.
The storybook toolkit consists of
Writing Stories â€” This is a single independent UI component or function that captures and renders the UI component's state.
Writing Docs â€” The Storybook provides developers with the inbuilt documentation feature to explain the in-depth application of stories they have created.
Add-ons â€” The Storybook provides plugins like WordPress, which helps users extend the Storybook's â€¦
articles.title: Getting Started with Storybook

GA4 is the new version of Google  Analytics. Universal   Analytics shortly UA, also known as GA3, is the previous version. With this technology, new features were brought, and existing features were improved. It is called Google Analytics 3 because it is not a product that receives Universal Analytics core updates. Since Google Analytics 4 is a more advanced service, Google suggests parallel tracking - not directly using ONLY UA but UA and GA4 together.
While these suggestions can be made through communication channels such as e-mail for users who already have accounts, At the same time, the instructions created under the "GA4 Setup Assistant" title in the Property section provide a guide for its users to start using GA4. If the user does not have an account, the account and property can bâ€¦

articles.author: Ryosuke
articles.description:
I finished this great wgpu tutorial that gets you up and running with WebGPU and Rust using the wgpu crate. It teaches you to setup the graphic context and render pipeline, import and render a textured model, and even add lighting. You can see the end result in this video:
@whoisryosuke
      
#wgpu #rust 
    
Afterwards though, you end up with a few modules, but most of the code is in one giant file. In a real application, youâ€™d probably split up a lot of the functionality happening into reusable modules. I started to ask myself: how would I render multiple models with different textures â€” or an entire scene?
I thought Iâ€™d share my approach as I take the wgpu tutorial code and refactor it. Weâ€™ll split the functionality out and build in an architecture to allow for a flat scene of 3D modeâ€¦
articles.title: Render Pipelines in wgpu and Rust

articles.author: Opensource.com
articles.description:
17 open source technologists share their favorite keyboards
Opensource.com
Sat, 11/19/2022 - 03:00

            
Keyboards are necessary to work with a computer system whether it's for coding, writing, or moving around items in a spreadsheet. They allow access to a computer's peripherals and are used to get deep into the operating system of any computer. Keyboards come in all shapes and sizes.Â Some are more comfortable to use than others. We asked our community members to share the best (and the worst) keyboard they'd ever used. Some of the answers might surprise you!
Top 4 favorite keyboards
Keyboards rank right after editors and languages on the official list of things that programmers argue about.
My favorite keyboards:
NeXT Extended Keyboard: With the pipe in the right place.
Apple Macâ€¦
articles.title: 17 open source technologists share their favorite keyboards

articles.author: Dwayne McDaniel
articles.description:
My favorite Git tools
Dwayne McDaniel
Fri, 11/18/2022 - 03:00

            
As with any other technology or skill, just reading about Git cannot make you proficient at it or make you an "advanced" user. Now it's time to dig into some of the tools in Git that I've found useful, and hopefully, that will help you use Git.
Git reflog
In my previous article, I wrote about Git history as a chain of commits, and that's a very good model for most purposes. However, Git actually remembers everything you do with Git, not just commits. You can see your entire recent history with git reflog.
  
Image by: 
(Dwayne McDaniel, CC BY-SA 4.0)
The log that reflog refers to is found in .git/logs, and it's called HEAD. Opening this file, you can quickly see all the actions taken recently. Inside .git/logs/HEADâ€¦
articles.title: My favorite Git tools

articles.author: Seth Kenlon
articles.description:
Get verified on Mastodon with your website
Seth Kenlon
Fri, 11/18/2022 - 03:00

            
If you're migrating away from Twitter, you might be looking for a way to ensure your followers that you are who you say you are. Ignoring debates of how anyone can be sure of anyone's true identity online, it's easy to verify yourself on Mastodon if you already have your own website. This requires a very basic understanding of HTML, so if you don't maintain your own website, then send this article to your web maintainer instead.
1. Get your verification code
Sign in to your Mastodon account and click the edit profile link under your Mastodon handle.
  
Image by: 
(Seth Kenlon, CC BY-SA 4.0)
In the Edit Profile screen that appears, scroll down to the Verification section. This section contains a speâ€¦
articles.title: Get verified on Mastodon with your website

articles.author: Dwayne McDaniel
articles.description:
Git concepts in less than 10 minutes
Dwayne McDaniel
Thu, 11/17/2022 - 03:00

            
Git has become the default way to store and transport code in the DevOps generation. Over 93% of developers report that Git is their primary version control system. Almost anyone who has used version control is familiar with git add, git commit, and git push. For most users, thatâ€™s all they ever plan to do with Git, and they're comfortable with that. It just works for their needs.
However, from time to time, almost everyone encounters the need to do something a little more advanced, like git rebase or git cherry-pick or work in a detached head state. This is where many devs start to get a bit nervous.
[ Read nextÂ How to reset, revert, and return to previous states in Git ]
I'm here to tell you it is â€¦
articles.title: Git concepts in less than 10 minutes

articles.author: Seth Kenlon
articles.description:
Linux commands: Drop these old utilities for modern alternatives
Seth Kenlon
Thu, 11/17/2022 - 03:00

            
Linux has a good track record for software support. There are about 60 commands in man section 1 of Unix 1st edition, and the majority still work today. Still, progress stops for no one. Thanks to vast global participation in open source, new commands are frequently developed. Sometimes a new command gains popularity, usually because it offers new features, or the same features but with consistent maintenance. Here are ten old commands that have recently been reinvented.
1. Replace man with cheat or tealdeer
The man page is functional, and it works well for what it does. However, man pages aren't always the most succinct at demonstrating how to use the command you're trying toâ€¦
articles.title: Linux commands: Drop these old utilities for modern alternatives

articles.author: Gordon Haff
articles.description:
How open source powers innovation
Gordon Haff
Wed, 11/16/2022 - 03:00

            
Where do people come together to make cutting-edge invention and innovation happen?
The corporate lab
One possible answer is the corporate research lab. More long-term focused than most company product development efforts, corporate labs have a long history, going back to Thomas Edison's Menlo Park laboratory in New Jersey. Perhaps most famous is Bell Labs' invention of the transistorâ€”although software folks may associate it more with Unix and the C programming language.
But corporate laboratories have tended to be more associated with dominant firms that could afford to let large staffs work on very forward-looking and speculative research projects. After all, Bell Labs was born of the AT&T telephone monopâ€¦
articles.title: How open source powers innovation

articles.author: Georg Link
articles.description:
How to address challenges with community metrics
Georg Link
Wed, 11/16/2022 - 03:00

            
The previous two articles in this series looked at open source community health and the metrics used to understand it. They showed examples of how open source communities have measured at their health through metrics. This final article brings those ideas together, discussing the challenges of implementing community health metrics for your own community.
Organizational challenges
First, you must decide which metrics you want to examine. This requires understanding your questions about reaching your goals as a community. The metrics relevant to you are those that can answer your questions. Otherwise, you risk being overwhelmed by the amount of data available.
Second, you need to anticipate how â€¦
articles.title: How to address challenges with community metrics

articles.author: Anamika
articles.description:
My favorite tricks for navigating the Linux terminal faster
Anamika
Tue, 11/15/2022 - 03:00

            
One of the advantages of working in a terminal is that it's faster than most other interfaces. Thanks to the GNU ReadlineÂ library and the built-in syntax of shells like Bash and Zsh, there are several ways to make your interactions with the command line even faster. Here are five ways to make the most of your time in the terminal.
1. Navigate without the arrow keys
While executing commands on the command line, sometimes you miss a part at the beginning or forget to add certain tags or arguments toward the end. It's common for users to use the Left and Right arrow keys on the keyboard to move through a command to make edits.
There's a better way to get around the command line. You can mâ€¦
articles.title: My favorite tricks for navigating the Linux terminal faster

articles.author: Georg Link
articles.description:
What do you do with community metrics?
Georg Link
Tue, 11/15/2022 - 03:00

            
In myÂ previous article, I provided an overview of possible community health metrics. I look at what you can do with those metrics in this article. You'll see several examples from different communities, some of which you may be familiar with.
Contribution metric
I'll start with the "new contributors and contributions" metric, which measures developers joining and leaving a community. I can measure this by seeing which developers made a commit during a specific period. Someone who shows up for the first time joined. Someone who hasn't contributed for a while has probably left.
It is natural for developers to leave a project. Maybe they change jobs, have a change in priorities, or have personal reasons foâ€¦
articles.title: What do you do with community metrics?

articles.author: Georg Link
articles.description:
5 metrics to track in your open source community
Georg Link
Mon, 11/14/2022 - 03:00

            
The core of open source is about using, sharing, and collaborating in software creation. With its roots in the free software movement and ensuring the rights of software users, open source has evolved from being solely the work of volunteers and hobbyists to also include the enterprise.
Collaborative software development has taken on a new dimension in the last 5 to 10 years. Today open source makes up 58% of software in the enterprise. In fact, 63% of companies in a 2021 survey indicated wanting to increase their use and engagement with open source.
Open source is everywhere and forms the digital infrastructure we rely on. The US issued a directive mandating more software supply chain securitâ€¦
articles.title: 5 metrics to track in your open source community

articles.description:
@nrek ) and in 2017 I started to put an application together to address the Tokyo 2020 Olympics called Wandur. The market research, consumer analysis, application POC, and various other aspects of the product were all pieced together through the end of 2019, with a  plan to launch at the end of Q4 2019. 

COVID. 

Well, everything got put on hold, and the Olympics came and went. Now, here we are, post-pandemic, 5 years after the inception of an idea, 3 years after developing the POC, and just a few months after vaccination cards and mask requirements have been lifted, ready to rock again. 

The launch phase of Wandur lacks layers of complexity to focus on user acquisition by providing curated maps that help navigate landmarks through scenic areas of walkable tourist destinations. This period exists to allow Wandur to accumulate gig workers who will operate as travel guides/companions. The path is pretty straightforward - gather users, make guides available, and release follow-up features based on app usage. 

It's just a matter of marketing, timing, and narrow focus - it's why we've chosen Rome, Italy as the first city where Wandur will be available. Wandur is set to launch in early/mid 2023.
              â€

articles.description:
@itsmaleen, I'm super stoked to introduce Jive ğŸ˜Š

Why Jive
==========
The main thing that keeps us coming back to Twitter is the content. Specifically, the nuggets of value hidden in great threads written by brilliant builders and creators. From how-tos to opinion pieces, we've found that threads are a treasure trove of information that rival any blog.

The Problem
==========
Although there is a lot of value in Twitter threads, and that creators put lots of time / energy into creating them, there is no real place for them to live permanently. Too often do great threads fade away in the avalanche of new content. Now that there is some concern about the future of the platform, we want to ensure that no content gets lost.

The Solution
==========
So, why not help creators turn their already written out content into a personal blog? Well, that's what we did.

For Creators:
âœï¸ Automatically turn threads into a personal blog
ğŸ“ˆ Track analytics across topics and posts
ğŸ”­ Have your content discoverable with a new audience

For Readers:
ğŸ§­ Explore new topics and creators
ğŸ”– Bookmark relevant threads
ğŸ–¤ Follow topics that interest you

If you want an easier way to go through valuable Twitter content without the noise, or if you want to leverage your existing work, join Jive!

Coming soon: export your Twitter threads to publishing platforms you love (whether that's Jive, Medium, Mirror, etc.)

ğŸª„ AI Editor

A graphics-like editor based on an infinite canvas putting different AI models together in one interface. An advanced and professional tool that can be used for:
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Outpainting â†’ expanding pictures beyond their original borders
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Inpainting â†’ erasing part of an image and filling it with new objects based on a given text
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Text to image â†’ generating images with just text
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Image to image â†’ modifying the style of an image
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Find & Replace â†’ replacing parts of an image using only text, e.g., replace "t-shirt." with a "suit."
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Face enhancement â†’ improving the quality of generated faces


ğŸ“ Text to Image

Simple interface for generating images with just text. Great start for AI art beginners that offers more advanced users the possibility to play with a set of generation guiding parameters.

A tool for modifying existing images or generating their variations with text prompts. Best for changing the style of the picture, e.g., "make this image look like van Gogh painting."

articles.description:
About Us
My name is Moonish and I co-created Lumos Health (Lumos) with my friend, Esteban. We are both data-nerds, economists, and big on personal finance. We created Lumos to help people save money and bring more transparency to the US health insurance industry.

Problem Statement
When we both quit our corporate jobs earlier this year and became self-employed, we had to pick our own health insurance using healthcare.gov and only then  realized how difficult it was to pick the right plan, especially from a financial perspective.

After more research, we realized that most Americans ( insurance brokers included) struggle to make the right financial choice, overpaying by an estimated ~$400-$1,250 annually. Picking the right plan assumes you know how much youâ€™ll pay in both premiums AND out-oâ€¦
